channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: She helped him flee a rally, then learned he was a right-wing provocateur
item.description: Jake Lang, a pardoned Jan. 6 rioter, jumped into a stranger’s car after he was driven from his anti-immigrant march in Minneapolis by a large counterprotest.

item.title: Justice Department considering rollback of gun regulations, seeking to bolster support from Second Amendment advocates
item.description: The administration seeks to placate gun-rights groups that have criticized Attorney General Pam Bondi. Some of the changes are expected to ease restrictions on the private sale of guns and loosen regulations around shipping firearms.

item.title: Public health groups file lawsuit to reverse RFK Jr.’s new vaccine guidance for children
item.description: Several health organizations are suing to overturn a decision from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, arguing that Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others failed to consider how the policy would endanger families and burden the health care system.

item.title: How to dress better with the 3-3-3 rule and 6 other numerical guides
item.description: Experts break down all those viral fashion recommendations — what works, what to tweak and one to avoid.

item.title: Fashion giant Valentino Garavani, who dressed Hollywood and royalty, dies at 93
item.description: The mononymously known Italian couturier died Monday at his house in Rome.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Does she have to accept boyfriend’s staggering lateness?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Does she have to accept boyfriend’s staggering lateness?

item.title: Rich people are leaving California, inspired by tech founders’ online campaign
item.description: Industry leaders long critical of San Francisco have fueled opposition to a proposed billionaire tax, prompting some of the state’s richest to relocate.

item.title: The White House wanted an ICE spectacle. It backfired.
item.description: The shooting of Renée Good in Minneapolis may mark a turning point in public opinion.

item.title: Trump ties Greenland takeover bid to Nobel Prize snub in text to Norway leader as tariff threats shake transatlantic alliance
item.description: The president said in the weekend message to Norwegian Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store that he no longer needed to “think purely of Peace” after he didn't get the Nobel Peace Prize last year.

item.title: A question for the long weekend in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Minneapolis protests. Greenland. ‘Board of Peace.’ Train crash. Wealth tax. Weight-loss drugs. Dry days. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: A 6,000-seat immersive ‘mini-Sphere’ venue is planned for D.C. region
item.description: The smaller cousin of the famed Sphere in Las Vegas is expected by Maryland officials to generate $1 billion in annual economic activity after it’s built at National Harbor.

item.title: Homeowners don’t want to move. It’s a big deal for their shrinking backyards.
item.description: The American backyard is getting smaller, as some owners with low mortgage rates opt to expand their homes instead of move.

item.title: This startup is selling an EV that charges in five minutes. Scientists have doubts.
item.description: The high-end electric motorcycle maker Verge Motorcycles and its spin-off motor company Donut Lab say they’re selling the world’s first EV powered by a “solid-state” battery.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: She brought her political dissent to Stephen Miller’s home. Now police are investigating.
item.description: Barbara Wien, 66-year-old retired peace studies professor, says she was taking a stand against the Trump administration’s policies. To Katie Miller, married to one of the president’s most powerful aides, Wien’s actions appeared to be a threat.

item.title: Pentagon readies 1,500 soldiers to possibly deploy to Minnesota, officials say
item.description: Though no decisions have been announced, soldiers with the Army’s 11th Airborne Division in Alaska have been placed at the ready following Trump’s Insurrection Act threat, according to defense officials.

item.title: These prophets of economic doom are worried about another collapse
item.description: They called the dot-com and housing bubbles. Now they're worried about the AI investment boom.

item.title: Behind Trump's decision to back away from striking Iran
item.description: The president confronted the limits of U.S. military power as costs loomed and Mideast allies lobbied for restraint.

item.title: Dan Bongino stoked ‘deep state’ conspiracy theories. Now they’re coming back to haunt him.
item.description: Bongino’s stint as the FBI’s deputy director has alienated some of his online followers as he relaunches his podcast career.

item.title: Abigail Spanberger sworn in as Virginia’s first female governor
item.description: Spanberger, a former Democratic member of Congress and undercover operative for the CIA, became Virginia’s first female governor Saturday. She takes office after a landslide victory and a centrist message focused on affordability and defending the commonwealth from President Trump’s policies.

item.title: Trump announces tariffs on European countries opposing Greenland takeover
item.description: The move escalates tensions between the U.S. and longtime allies that have been sending Trump a message that the territory of Denmark is not for sale.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: The definitive ranking of the best sitcom neighbors in TV history
item.description: They’re intrusive. They’re perceptive. They’re infuriating. And they’ve nearly vanished.

item.title: Federal judge bars DHS agents in Minneapolis from arresting or retaliating against peaceful protesters
item.description: The order comes in response to a lawsuit from local residents alleging that federal agents violated their constitutional rights while they were observing or protesting immigration raids.

item.title: Young men are finding happiness in their parents’ homes — and they’re not going anywhere
item.description: During a time of acute anxiety and curiosity about young men in America, more of them are embracing the living-with-parents lifestyle.

item.title: U-Va. board leaders resign, attorneys at two other Virginia colleges are dismissed as Spanberger and Democrats take power
item.description: The departures come as Democrats push to unwind some changes made at Virginia colleges and universities during the administration of Republican Gov. Glenn Youngkin. Some schools have also faced intense scrutiny from the Trump administration and other conservatives over diversity, equity and inclusion policies, the response to antisemitism, and the provision of gender transition care, among other topics.

item.title: Justice Department issues subpoenas for Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey as part of criminal investigation
item.description: The subpoenas, which are without recent precedent, escalate an already bitter political battle between the Trump administration and Democratic state officials following the fatal shooting of a woman in Minneapolis by an immigration officer last week.

item.title: Trump officials extend National Guard’s D.C. mission through 2026, two defense officials familiar with plan say
item.description: The domestic military mission, which is the subject of an ongoing court challenge, was due to expire at the end of February. The National Guard headquarters overseeing the mission said that 2,673 troops were assigned to the mission as of Friday morning.

item.title: Yulia Navalnaya, Alexei Navalny’s widow: Dictators are coming for the lawyers
item.description: "The persecution of my husband’s lawyers shows how authoritarian power eliminates dissent at its source," Navalnaya writes.

item.title: Trump installs loyalists on panel to review White House ballroom to secure rapid approval
item.description: The Commission of Fine Arts will discuss the controversial project next week. Officials hope to win approval in two months, while some past White House projects have taken years to green light.

item.title: Family of man shot in the leg by ICE in Minneapolis disputes key aspects of DHS account
item.description: Relatives say the non-fatal shooting occurred at the door of the house, not out in the street during a scuffle. They also say the victim was not the man a federal officer tried to arrest in a traffic stop.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: My spouse yelled at my sister. Now she doesn't feel safe with him.
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: My spouse yelled at my sister. Now she doesn't feel safe with him.

item.title: Washington National Opera announces new venues after split with Kennedy Center
item.description: The company has lined up Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University for two upcoming operas, and has also seen a spike in donations since it announced last week that it was leaving the Kennedy Center, which has been transformed under President Donald Trump.

item.title: America’s most elusive founder has lessons for today
item.description: With “Common Sense,” published 250 years ago this month, Thomas Paine was just getting started.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Insurrection Act. Detainee death. Nobel Prize. Outraged judge. Political violence. Psychiatric disorders. Terrapin. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: 25 ways travel has changed so far this century
item.description: Cruise ships used to be about sailing and the sea. If you wanted to rent a room, you went to a hotel. Those were such quaint times. Our staff discussed the biggest travel moments and advances that took place between 2000 and 2025, and we asked industry stalwarts for theirs.

item.title: Medical examiner believes death of man at ICE detention center in Texas was homicide, recording says
item.description: A fellow detainee says he witnessed Geraldo Lunas Campos, a 55-year-old Cuban immigrant, being choked to death by guards on Jan. 3.

item.title: The Pentagon said it plans to overhaul the newspaper, calling it ‘woke.’ Its top editor pledged to defend its independence.
item.description: The Pentagon will “modernize” the publication and “refocus its content away from woke distractions that syphon morale, and adapt it to serve a new generation of service members,” chief Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell wrote on X. A spokesperson for the Defense Department did not answer questions about how the changes would comply with the newspaper’s long-standing editorial independence.

item.title: Dozens of bettors and players fixed NCAA and Chinese Basketball Association games, prosecutors say
item.description: Sports bettors worked with players across NCAA men’s basketball to rig the outcome of at least 29 games, federal prosecutors alleged in an indictment unsealed Thursday. The athletes played for schools across the country, including Tulane, St. Louis University, DePaul, Fordham and others, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

item.title: Who used the Maduro raid to earn $400K? The pool of suspects is alarming.
item.description: A bet on government action by a government actor is always a bet against the public interest.

item.title: These workers are striking in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act in Minnesota to quell ICE protests
item.description: The Insurrection Act enables a president to deploy the military on U.S. soil in extraordinary circumstances: to quell an insurrection, civil disorder or armed rebellion. It empowers the military to make arrests and perform searches domestically.

item.title: First renderings of the Commanders’ new stadium show plenty of callbacks to RFK Stadium
item.description: The most striking features include a translucent roof, a grand colonnade and main entryways on the same axis as the Washington Monument and the U.S. Capitol. While the design process is ongoing, the renderings reflect the major design principles agreed upon by the team and the lead architects.

item.title: Minneapolis tensions. Iran protests. Greenland talks. FBI search. Missing jobs. Cancer treatment. Microplastics. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Federal agent shoots person in leg as Minneapolis protests flare
item.description: In a statement, Department of Homeland Security alleged that an individual attempted to evade arrest by driving their vehicle away from federal law enforcement officers, crashing it into a parked car and then running away on foot. Both the officer and the person shot were being treated at a hospital.

item.title: She made a Facebook comment about her mayor. Then the police arrived.
item.description: Raquel Pacheco says she was asserting her right to free speech. Miami Beach police said they dispatched officers to assess whether there was a safety threat.

item.title: Senate blocks Venezuela war powers bill after Vance breaks deadlock
item.description: The vote failed after two Republicans withdrew their previous support under intense pressure from the Trump administration.
